Award.AwardTitle: Interactions of Multiple Phase Transformations and Dislocations: Modeling and Simulation from Atomistic to Microscale

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental research to provide knowledge toward understanding phase transformations, plasticity, and their interactions. The research under this award will focus on phase transformation and plasticity in silicon and germanium. Predicting the deformation response in these materials is important for semiconductor engineering. This research will lead to a multifaceted computational tool for quantitative predictions of properties of these materials. The computer simulations enabled by the computational tool would reveal the main mechanisms during the interaction between phase transformation and plasticity from the atomic to the macroscopic level. As an extension, the computational tool can also find applications to other material processes and technologies, including the thermomechanical treatment of steel, the behavior of shape memory alloys, and the synthesis of superhard ceramics. The software developed under this award will be shared with the research community on the team's webpages and high performance computing clusters. The research team will also participate the Freshman Honor Program that connects undergraduates with research activities at Iowa State University. Two new graduate courses on phase transformations and plasticity, and atomistic-continuum modeling will be developed. This research will also promote active participation from under-represented groups through the Program for Women and Science in Engineering in the College of Engineering at Iowa State University.

The objective of this research is to establish a predictive multiscale modeling framework by linking a reactive concurrent atomistic-continuum method and a continuum phase field approach. The reactive concurrent atomistic-continuum method will be based on a finite element implementation of an atomistic field formalism. Simultaneous phase transformations and dislocation-mediated plasticity as a consequence of chemical bond breaking and reforming, changes of the crystal structures and slip will be simulated for micron-sized domains of silicon and germanium. The phase field approach will be based on a new multiphase thermodynamic potential for large strains and will enable large-scale simulations of coupled phase transformation and plasticity in materials. Formations of multiple phases and evolutions of dislocation microstructures in silicon and germanium will be simulated at the macroscale. The research team will validate the predictive capability of the multiscale computational tool through fully atomistic simulations and also experimental measurements. Lastly, the team will apply the multiscale simulation tools to find methods for promoting or suppressing dislocation activities and phase transformations through tailoring the microstructures of materials and controlling applied loading conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop an atomistic-to-mesoscopic computational platform for understanding the phase transformations (PTs), dislocations, and their interactions in  materials, to reveal the mechanisms, and to find methods of controlling them for designing new materials with exceptional properties.

Intellectual Merit:

[1] A determination of the atomistic mechanisms responsible for the structure changes induced by the reactions between dislocations and interfaces in Si through high-fidelity atomic-level computer simulations:

(1a) a quantification of the effects of the atomic-level grain boundary (GB) structures on the dislocation activities; a measurement of the barrier strength of the GBs when they act as the obstacles to dislocations;

(1b) an elucidation of the atomic-level amorphization process in silicon, providing an direct evidence of utilizing the dislocation pileup to manipulate the PTs in multi-phase materials with desired properties.

[2] Formulation of a lattice instability criterion that can be used in continuum-level computer models for predicting the PTs in multi-phase materials under deformation, calibrated through atomistic simulations:

(2a) a combination of the generalized Landau-type theory and atomistic simulations for direct and reverse PTs between Si-I and Si-II and the establishment of an instability criterion based on the critical value of the modified transformation work for PTs in materials subject to a multiaxial stress;

(2b) the discovery of special tri-axial compression-tension intermediate states for direct and reverse PTs between Si-I and Si-II phases, and an arrest of the homogeneous and hysteresis-free first-order PTs in Si;

(2c) the derivation of the lattice instability conditions to describe the PTs between Si-I and Si-II under the action of a general stress tensor and its validation through density functional theory (DFT) calculations;

(2d) the development of a phase field approach (PFA) that uses the atomistic-based lattice instability criterion as an input for modeling the stress- and temperature-induced microstructure evolution mediated by  direct and reverse PTs between Si-I and Si-II phases in Si under deformation at the continuum level.

[3] the delivery of a concurrent atomistic-continuum (CAC) computer simulation tool that can be used to predict the dislocation-GB reactions and the subsequent PTs in multiphase materials under deformation.

(3a) the wrap up of CAC with a Python scripting interface, which lead to an interactive, efficient, user-friendly, and extensible multiscale material modeling platform available at www.pycac.org;

(3b) a massive parallelization of the CAC simulator for predicting the mesoscale dislocation activities in micron-sized metallic materials containing billions of atoms using 1000+ computing processors.

[4] the formulation of a microscale PFA for modeling the PT, dislocation evolution, and their interactions in materials under large strains, a benchmark of it within the framework of finite element method (FEM):

(4a) an incorporation of the atomistic mechanisms for the dislocation pileup-assisted PTs into the PFA, and a demonstration of the possibility of activating a PT in multiphase materials even under a zero pressure;

(4b) the development of a large-strain PFA for simulating the single-variant PT in silicon and the multi-variant martensitic PT in other materials; an implementation of it in Deal-II, which is a C++ open source program library aimed at the computer solution of partial differential equations using an adaptive FEM;

(4c) the publication of an invited review paper about the PTs in materials under high pressure torsion;

(4d) the delivery of a scale-free modeling approach for the coupled evolution of the discrete dislocation bands and multi-variant martensitic microstructure for the plastic strain-induced PTs in materials;

(4e) the development of a system of imaging the internal stress in materials under high pressure using a nanoscale quantum sensor under a collaboration between multiple institutes (Berkley, Geophysical Laboratory, ISU). Using this technique, all components of the stress tensor in materials under deformation in the entire anvil were determined by a combined experiment and simulation.

Broad Impacts (major outcomes): Three PhD students have graduated. Two post-doc and seven undergraduate US students (two of whom are female) have worked on this project.  The PIs have developed and taught new research-oriented graduate classes called Atomistic and Multiscale Computational Mechanics of Materials (AerE 515), Mechanics of Interface and Surface-Induced Phenomena, Nanomechanics of Materials, and Phase Transformations and Plasticity. The coPI also taught his significantly updated research-oriented graduate classes Phase Transformations in Elastic Materials, Continuum Mechanochemistry, Micromechanics of Structural Changes in Materials, and Phase Field Approach to Structural Changes.

Results of the project have been disseminated through 45 publications in highly-ranked journals, 46 conference talks (including several plenary lectures and more than 15 keynote and invited talks), and 10 invited seminars. The PIs organized/co-organized 14 symposia on the topic of the project.
